toytulini 161034945137 "2017-05-24 22:04:49 GMT" https://toytulini.tumblr.com/post/161034945137/fandomsandfeminism-i-really-think-hospitals-and "fandomsandfeminism:  I really think hospitals and doctors that work with pregnancy and pediatricians need to make more literature available for how to
column2: ya know
column3: work with kids? Â Because the more conversations we have about spanking (and how itâ€™s ineffective and harmful and does more bad than good)
column4: the more I realize that a lot of people donâ€™t know the alternatives. Or like
column5: anything about child development or where misbehavior stems from.Â  So
column6: as someone who went through childhood development classes in college
column7: works with kids for a living
column8: and knows multiple people who specialized in childhood education
column9: here are some pointers when you are working with kids: 1. Model emotional response for kids. Children are learning how to recognize and respond to their own emotions. All the way up through high school
column11: and the emotions they are learning to process become more complex. So with really young kids
column12: the easiest way to help them with this is to model emotional self awareness and self care.Â  â€œOh wow
column13: mommy is feeling angry because the cat made a mess. Iâ€™m going to clean this mess and then go sit in my room in the quiet for a short break so I feel better.â€ â€œYou know
column14: I am feeling very sad about not going to the park because it is raining. I bet some hot chocolate and a book would make me feel better.â€ â€Huh
column15: Iâ€™m feeling kind of cranky and hungry
column16: but daddy wonâ€™t be home for dinner for another hour. I bet Iâ€™ll feel better if I eat a little piece apple while we wait.â€Â  2. Understand what causes child frustration and work to preempt it.Â  -Transitions (from one activity to another
column19: especially if the activity or location they are leaving is fun. Give kids a warning when this is going to happen. With young kids
column20: give them about 5-15 minutes of warning (â€10 minutes until we are going to leave the park and go home. Do your last thing.â€)
column22: just give them a time frame. (We are can play at McDonalds for 30 minutes
column23: but then we have to go grocery shopping
column24: ok?)Â Not being able to communicate what they want to is frustrating. Babies can learn simplified baby sign language months before they are verbal. Kids may not know the words for what they are trying to say. Be patient and help them find the right words. On a similar note
column25: donâ€™t ignore kids. If you really canâ€™t respond to their question right away because of something else
column27: I heard your question. Iâ€™ll answer you as soon as Iâ€™m done talking on the phone.â€Not being able to make choices or having too much choice can be overwhelming. Give kids a limited
column28: reasonable selection of choices.Â â€œDo you want apple slices or juicy pears on the side for lunch?â€ is much better thanÂ â€œWhat do you want with your sandwich?â€ or just giving them apple slices.Â â€œDo you want to give grandpa a hug or a high five?â€ is better than demanding they hug grandpa right away.Â 3. Understand that kids are people to. They will get hungry
column30: an annoyed just like adults do. Sometimes you have to be flexible and give them time to self care. Talk to them
column32: let them be people and not just dolls. Â â€œBecause I said soâ€ is really unhelpful for a growing kid.Â â€œWe canâ€™t buy Fruit Loops today because we are already getting Frosted Flakes. We only need one cereal at a time.â€ is going to do you a lot more favors.Â â€œDonâ€™t pick up the glass snow globe. It belongs to grandma and can break easy. She would be sad if we broke it on accident.â€ is better thanÂ â€œdonâ€™t touch that.â€Â   And look
column33: no parent is perfect. No baby sitter
column35: no care taker is going to be awesome all the time. And no kid is going to be perfect. They will cry and have tantrums
column36: and not be able to tell you what they need
column37: and be stubborn sometimes. Sometimes they need space
column38: or quiet time. Sometimes they need attention and validation.Â   But kids learn from every interaction they have
column39: so adults need to make the effort to show all the love
column42: and thoughtfulness we want them to learn.Â  " False text

column1: toytulini 161033730342 "2017-05-24 21:25:56 GMT" https://toytulini.tumblr.com/post/161033730342/can-we-talk-about-how-soulmates-are-damaging "syntax-forest: The concept that everyone has One True Love somewhere out there
column2: waiting
column3: erases aromantic and polyamorous experiences. And you can say that polyamorous people have more than one
column4: and aromantic soulmates are platonic in natureâ€“erasing aplatonic aros in the processâ€“but thatâ€™s just a Band-Aid on the issue. The Soulmate Postulate is more insidious. Itâ€™s a mask for aphobia (you just havenâ€™t met The One). And I donâ€™t want to assume experiences of gay people
column5: but Iâ€™ve heard of it being used for homophobia as well. Especially lesbophobia (because they just havenâ€™t met the Right Man). â€œBut surely thatâ€™s not the fault of the Soulmate Postulate
column6: and everything will be fine once homophobia is eradicated.â€ Okay
column7: but no. Because the Soulmate Postulate still creates damaging mindsets when going into relationships. Because youâ€™re out there looking for the one (or
column9: three or so if youâ€™re polyamorous) person who can make you *really* happy. The person who *completes* you. Youâ€™re putting potential partners on a pedestal
column10: and if they donâ€™t meet these unrealistic expectations then it obviously wasnâ€™t meant to be. I never even considered I was aro in high school because I thought I was just being logical; if the purpose of dating was to find The One with whom you would spend your entire lifeâ€¦ what was the purpose of investing emotionally in finding something that I would be highly unlikely to find in my small high school. Itâ€™s all fine and well if you want to go looking for the one person in the world who can *really* complete your life or whatever
column11: but these messages are being broadcast to kids at very young ages.  High schoolers get together in movies
column13: and weâ€™re led to believe that all of the fourteen-year-olds that started dating will be together forever. Cinderellaâ€™s only known her prince for
column16: but itâ€™s okay because theyâ€™re destined for each other. Soulmate AUs are bandied about on this blue hellhole as though soulmates were just A Thing
column17: and the AU bit is that you only see in color when you meet them or something. And this is presented as positive or something. Likeâ€¦ I donâ€™t really expect to accomplish much with this. But can we at least start with not portraying the Soulmate Postulate as some universal constant that is the Height of Romance? â€˜Cause Iâ€™d really appreciate it and Iâ€™m sure there are other people who would

column1: toytulini 160176763917 "2017-05-01 03:14:45 GMT" https://toytulini.tumblr.com/post/160176763917/what-dogs-do-after-training-affects-how-much-they "herebelife: Think this has been shared around before but always good for a refresh reminder:  What goes on in the dogâ€™s brain does not stop when the training session ends. Some new data suggests that what you do after a training session may have an influence on how much your dog remembers and how well he subsequently performs.Â   However any emotionally arousing situation occurring immediately after a  training session can cause the body to create and secrete such  chemicals. One positive way to do this is to engage in playful activity  with the dog.   A â€œPlay Groupâ€ of eight dogs experienced a 30 minute session of intense  playful activity consisting of a 10 minute walk
column2: 10 minutes of off lead  play (which could include fetching a ball
column3: chasing after Frisbees
column4: or  playing tug-of-war depending on each dogâ€™s preferred play style)
column5: and  then a final 10 minute walk. For comparison purposes a â€œRest Groupâ€ of  eight dogs simply spent the 30 minutes after training resting on a dog  bed while the researcher engaged their owner in a conversation to  prevent further attention or interaction with the dog.    The dogs who had received the play session after training relearned the  task 40% faster than the dogs who rested after the training sessions (an  average number of 26 training trials for the play group versus 43  trials for the rest group). Thus it appears that the playful activity  following the teaching sessions helped to consolidate or â€œstamp inâ€ the  memories of what the dogs had learned.Â   The take-home message from this new research seems to be that the simple  addition of a session of playful activity after a period of training  can significantly add to the effectiveness and performance of a dog who  is learning a new set of skills.  " False link
